name: 1622_B. Berland Music
description:
Berland Music is a music streaming service built specifically to support Berland local artist. Its developers are currently working on a song recommendation module.

So imagine Monocarp got recommended n songs, numbered from 1 to n. The i-th song had its predicted rating equal to p_i, where 1 ≤ p_i ≤ n and every integer from 1 to n appears exactly once. In other words, p is a permutation.

After listening to each of them, Monocarp pressed either a like or a dislike button. Let his vote sequence be represented with a string s, such that s_i=0 means that he disliked the i-th song, and s_i=1 means that he liked it.

Now the service has to re-evaluate the song ratings in such a way that:

  * the new ratings q_1, q_2, ..., q_n still form a permutation (1 ≤ q_i ≤ n; each integer from 1 to n appears exactly once); 
  * every song that Monocarp liked should have a greater rating than every song that Monocarp disliked (formally, for all i, j such that s_i=1 and s_j=0, q_i>q_j should hold). 



Among all valid permutations q find the one that has the smallest value of ∑_{i=1}^n |p_i-q_i|, where |x| is an absolute value of x.

Print the permutation q_1, q_2, ..., q_n. If there are multiple answers, you can print any of them.

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10^4) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains a single integer n (1 ≤ n ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of songs.

The second line of each testcase contains n integers p_1, p_2, ..., p_n (1 ≤ p_i ≤ n) — the permutation of the predicted ratings.

The third line contains a single string s, consisting of n characters. Each character is either a 0 or a 1. 0 means that Monocarp disliked the song, and 1 means that he liked it.

The sum of n over all testcases doesn't exceed 2 ⋅ 10^5.

Output

For each testcase, print a permutation q — the re-evaluated ratings of the songs. If there are multiple answers such that ∑_{i=1}^n |p_i-q_i| is minimum possible, you can print any of them.

Example

Input


3
2
1 2
10
3
3 1 2
111
8
2 3 1 8 5 4 7 6
01110001


Output


2 1
3 1 2
1 6 5 8 3 2 4 7

Note

In the first testcase, there exists only one permutation q such that each liked song is rating higher than each disliked song: song 1 gets rating 2 and song 2 gets rating 1. ∑_{i=1}^n |p_i-q_i|=|1-2|+|2-1|=2.

In the second testcase, Monocarp liked all songs, so all permutations could work. The permutation with the minimum sum of absolute differences is the permutation equal to p. Its cost is 0.
prompt:
Berland Music is a music streaming service built specifically to support Berland local artists, and its developers are currently working on a song recommendation module. So imagine Monocarp got recommended n songs, numbered from 1 to n, and the i-th song had its predicted rating equal to p_i, where 1 ≤ p_i ≤ n. Every single integer from 1 to n appears once and only once; to put it differently, p is a permutation. After listening to each of them, Monocarp pressed either a like or a dislike button. Let his vote sequence be represented with a string s, such that s_i=0 implies that he disliked the i-th song, and s_i=1 means that he liked it. Now the service has to re-evaluate the song ratings in such a way that: * the new ratings q_1, q_2, ..., q_n still form a permutation (1 ≤ q_i ≤ n; each integer from 1 to n appears exactly once); * every song that Monocarp liked should have a greater rating than every song that Monocarp disliked. Formally, for all i, j such that s_i=1 and s_j=0, q_i>q_j should hold. Among all valid permutations q find the one that has the smallest value of ∑_{i=1}^n |p_i-q_i|, where |x| is an absolute value of x. Print the permutation q_1, q_2, ..., q_n. If there are multiple answers, you can print any of them.

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10^4) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains a single integer n (1 ≤ n ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of songs.

The sum of n over all testcases doesn't exceed 2 ⋅ 10^5.

Output

For each testcase, print a permutation q — the re-evaluated ratings of the songs. If there are multiple answers such that ∑_{i=1}^n |p_i-q_i| is minimum possible, you can print any of them.

In the second testcase, Monocarp liked all songs, so all permutations could work. The permutation with the minimum sum of absolute differences is the permutation equal to p. Its cost is 0.
repair_prompt:
Berland Music is a music streaming service built specifically to support Berland local artists, and its developers are currently working on a song recommendation module. So imagine Monocarp got recommended n songs, numbered from 1 to n, and the i-th song had its predicted rating equal to p_i, where 1 ≤ p_i ≤ n. Every single integer from 1 to n appears once and only once; to put it differently, p is a permutation. After listening to each of them, Monocarp pressed either a like or a dislike button. Let his vote sequence be represented with a string s, such that s_i=0 implies that he disliked the i-th song, and s_i=1 means that he liked it. Now the service has to re-evaluate the song ratings in such a way that: * the new ratings q_1, q_2, ..., q_n still form a permutation (1 ≤ q_i ≤ n; each integer from 1 to n appears exactly once); * every song that Monocarp liked should have a greater rating than every song that Monocarp disliked. Formally, for all i, j such that s_i=1 and s_j=0, q_i>q_j should hold. Among all valid permutations q find the one that has the smallest value of ∑_{i=1}^n |p_i-q_i|, where |x| is an absolute value of x. Print the permutation q_1, q_2, ..., q_n. If there are multiple answers, you can print any of them.

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10^4) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains a single integer n (1 ≤ n ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of songs.

The second line of each testcase contains n integers p_1, p_2, ..., p_n (1 ≤ p_i ≤ n) — the permutation of the predicted ratings.

The third line contains a single string s, consisting of n characters. Each character is either a 0 or a 1. 0 means that Monocarp disliked the song, and 1 means that he liked it.

The sum of n over all testcases doesn't exceed 2 ⋅ 10^5.

Output

For each testcase, print a permutation q — the re-evaluated ratings of the songs. If there are multiple answers such that ∑_{i=1}^n |p_i-q_i| is minimum possible, you can print any of them.

-------
Important Note: You must follow the input output format.  The code will be tested against multiple test cases and all the test cases must be passed.
Example

Input


3
2
1 2
10
3
3 1 2
111
8
2 3 1 8 5 4 7 6
01110001


Output


2 1
3 1 2
1 6 5 8 3 2 4 7

Note

In the first testcase, there exists only one permutation q such that each liked song is rating higher than each disliked song: song 1 gets rating 2 and song 2 gets rating 1. ∑_{i=1}^n |p_i-q_i|=|1-2|+|2-1|=2.

In the second testcase, Monocarp liked all songs, so all permutations could work. The permutation with the minimum sum of absolute differences is the permutation equal to p. Its cost is 0.
completions:
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def re_evaluate_ratings(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int], str]]) -> List[List[int]]:
    """Re-evaluate song ratings based on user feedback.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, List[int], str]]): List of test cases, each containing:
            - n (int): Number of songs.
            - p (List[int]): Predicted ratings permutation.
            - s (str): Feedback string where '1' means liked and '0' means disliked.

    Returns:
        List[List[int]]: List of re-evaluated ratings for each test case.
    """
    results = []

    for n, p, s in test_cases:
        liked = []
        disliked = []

        # Separate songs into liked and disliked based on feedback
        for i in range(n):
            if s[i] == '1':
                liked.append(p[i])
            else:
                disliked.append(p[i])

        # Sort liked and disliked songs
        liked.sort()
        disliked.sort()

        # Create the new permutation q
        q = [0] * n
        liked_index = 0
        disliked_index = 0

        # Assign ratings ensuring liked songs have higher ratings than disliked ones
        for i in range(n):
            if s[i] == '1':
                q[i] = liked[liked_index]
                liked_index += 1
            else:
                q[i] = disliked[disliked_index]
                disliked_index += 1

        results.append(q)

    return results

def main():
    # Read number of test cases
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []

    # Read each test case
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        p = list(map(int, input().split()))
        s = input().strip()
        test_cases.append((n, p, s))

    # Call the function and get results
    results = re_evaluate_ratings(t, test_cases)

    # Output results
    for result in results:
        print(' '.join(map(str, result)))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

from typing import List, Tuple

def reevaluate_ratings(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int], str]]) -> List[List[int]]:
    """Re-evaluate song ratings based on user feedback using a greedy approach.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, List[int], str]]): List of test cases, each containing:
            - n (int): Number of songs.
            - p (List[int]): Predicted ratings permutation.
            - s (str): Feedback string where '1' means liked and '0' means disliked.

    Returns:
        List[List[int]]: List of re-evaluated ratings for each test case.
    """
    results = []
    
    for n, p, s in test_cases:
        liked = []
        disliked = []
        
        # Separate songs into liked and disliked based on feedback
        for i in range(n):
            if s[i] == '1':
                liked.append(p[i])
            else:
                disliked.append(p[i])
        
        # Sort liked and disliked songs
        liked.sort()
        disliked.sort()
        
        # Assign new ratings
        q = [0] * n
        liked_index = 0
        disliked_index = 0
        
        # Assign the highest ratings to liked songs and lowest to disliked songs
        for i in range(n):
            if s[i] == '1':
                q[i] = liked[liked_index]
                liked_index += 1
            else:
                q[i] = disliked[disliked_index]
                disliked_index += 1
        
        results.append(q)
    
    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        p = list(map(int, input().split()))
        s = input().strip()
        test_cases.append((n, p, s))
    
    # Output interface
    results = reevaluate_ratings(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(' '.join(map(str, result)))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

from typing import List, Tuple

def reevaluate_ratings(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int], str]]) -> List[List[int]]:
    """Re-evaluate song ratings based on user feedback.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, List[int], str]]): List of test cases, each containing:
            - n (int): Number of songs.
            - p (List[int]): Permutation of predicted ratings.
            - s (str): String representing user feedback (0 for dislike, 1 for like).

    Returns:
        List[List[int]]: List of re-evaluated ratings for each test case.
    """
    results = []
    
    for n, p, s in test_cases:
        liked = []
        disliked = []
        
        # Separate liked and disliked songs
        for i in range(n):
            if s[i] == '1':
                liked.append(p[i])
            else:
                disliked.append(p[i])
        
        # Sort liked and disliked songs
        liked.sort()
        disliked.sort()
        
        # Create new permutation q
        q = [0] * n
        liked_index = 0
        disliked_index = 0
        
        # Assign ratings ensuring liked songs have higher ratings
        for i in range(n):
            if s[i] == '1':
                q[i] = disliked_index + len(disliked) + 1
                liked_index += 1
            else:
                q[i] = disliked_index + 1
                disliked_index += 1
        
        results.append(q)
    
    return results

# Input interface

from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def reevaluate_ratings(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int], str]]) -> List[List[int]]:
    """Re-evaluate song ratings based on user likes and dislikes.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, List[int], str]]): List of test cases, each containing:
            - n (int): Number of songs.
            - p (List[int]): Predicted ratings permutation.
            - s (str): String of likes ('1') and dislikes ('0').

    Returns:
        List[List[int]]: List of re-evaluated ratings for each test case.
    """
    results = []

    for n, p, s in test_cases:
        liked = []
        disliked = []

        # Separate songs into liked and disliked based on the string s
        for i in range(n):
            if s[i] == '1':
                liked.append(p[i])
            else:
                disliked.append(p[i])

        # Sort liked and disliked songs
        liked.sort()
        disliked.sort()

        # Assign new ratings
        q = [0] * n
        liked_index = n - len(liked)
        disliked_index = 0

        for i in range(n):
            if s[i] == '1':
                q[i] = liked[liked_index]
                liked_index += 1
            else:
                q[i] = disliked[disliked_index]
                disliked_index += 1

        results.append(q)

    return results

def main():
    """Main function to handle input and output."""
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        p = list(map(int, input().split()))
        s = input().strip()
        test_cases.append((n, p, s))

    results = reevaluate_ratings(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(' '.join(map(str, result)))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def reevaluate_ratings(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int], str]]) -> List[List[int]]:
    """Re-evaluate song ratings based on Monocarp's feedback.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, List[int], str]]): List of test cases, each containing:
            - n (int): Number of songs.
            - p (List[int]): Predicted ratings permutation.
            - s (str): Feedback string where '1' means liked and '0' means disliked.

    Returns:
        List[List[int]]: List of re-evaluated ratings for each test case.
    """
    results = []
    
    for n, p, s in test_cases:
        liked = []
        disliked = []
        
        # Separate songs into liked and disliked based on feedback
        for i in range(n):
            if s[i] == '1':
                liked.append((p[i], i))
            else:
                disliked.append((p[i], i))
        
        # Sort liked and disliked songs by their predicted ratings
        liked.sort()
        disliked.sort()
        
        # Assign new ratings
        q = [0] * n
        current_rating = 1
        
        # Assign ratings to disliked songs first
        for _, index in disliked:
            q[index] = current_rating
            current_rating += 1
        
        # Assign ratings to liked songs
        for _, index in liked:
            q[index] = current_rating
            current_rating += 1
        
        results.append(q)
    
    return results

def main():
    """Main function to handle input and output."""
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        p = list(map(int, input().split()))
        s = input().strip()
        test_cases.append((n, p, s))
    
    results = reevaluate_ratings(t, test_cases)
    
    for result in results:
        print(' '.join(map(str, result)))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

def reevaluate_ratings(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int], str]]) -> List[List[int]]:
    """Re-evaluate song ratings based on user feedback using permutation logic.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, List[int], str]]): List of test cases, each containing:
            - n (int): Number of songs.
            - p (List[int]): Permutation of predicted ratings.
            - s (str): String representing user feedback (0 for dislike, 1 for like).

    Returns:
        List[List[int]]: List of re-evaluated ratings for each test case.
    """
    results = []
    
    for n, p, s in test_cases:
        liked = []
        disliked = []
        
        # Separate liked and disliked songs based on feedback
        for i in range(n):
            if s[i] == '1':
                liked.append(p[i])
            else:
                disliked.append(p[i])
        
        # Sort liked and disliked songs
        liked.sort()
        disliked.sort()
        
        # Create new permutation q
        q = [0] * n
        liked_index = n - len(liked)
        disliked_index = 0
        
        # Assign ratings ensuring liked songs have higher ratings
        for i in range(n):
            if s[i] == '1':
                q[i] = liked[liked_index]
                liked_index += 1
            else:
                q[i] = disliked[disliked_index]
                disliked_index += 1
        
        results.append(q)
    
    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        p = list(map(int, input().split()))
        s = input().strip()
        test_cases.append((n, p, s))
    
    # Output interface
    results = reevaluate_ratings(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(' '.join(map(str, result)))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

We will implement a function to re-evaluate song ratings based on user feedback using permutation logic. The function will ensure that liked songs have higher ratings than disliked ones and will optimize for minimal absolute difference from the original ratings. We will use Python's built-in sorting and list manipulation capabilities to achieve this efficiently.
examples:
Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10^4) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains a single integer n (1 ≤ n ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of songs.

The second line of each testcase contains n integers p_1, p_2, ..., p_n (1 ≤ p_i ≤ n) — the permutation of the predicted ratings.

The third line contains a single string s, consisting of n characters. Each character is either a 0 or a 1. 0 means that Monocarp disliked the song, and 1 means that he liked it.

The sum of n over all testcases doesn't exceed 2 ⋅ 10^5.

Output

For each testcase, print a permutation q — the re-evaluated ratings of the songs. If there are multiple answers such that ∑_{i=1}^n |p_i-q_i| is minimum possible, you can print any of them.

Example

Input


3
2
1 2
10
3
3 1 2
111
8
2 3 1 8 5 4 7 6
01110001


Output


2 1
3 1 2
1 6 5 8 3 2 4 7

Note

In the first testcase, there exists only one permutation q such that each liked song is rating higher than each disliked song: song 1 gets rating 2 and song 2 gets rating 1. ∑_{i=1}^n |p_i-q_i|=|1-2|+|2-1|=2.

In the second testcase, Monocarp liked all songs, so all permutations could work. The permutation with the minimum sum of absolute differences is the permutation equal to p. Its cost is 0.
